text.0: now mitravaruṇa shall be exalted high by your songs noblest of all existing.
text.1: they who as twere with reins are best controllers unequalled with their arms to check the people.
text.2: to you two gods is this my thought extended turned to the sacred grass with loving homage.
text.3: give us o mitravaruṇa a dwelling safe from attack which ye shall guard boongivers.
text.4: come hither mitravaruṇa invited with eulogies and loving adoration.
text.5: ye who with your might as workcontrollers urge even men who quickly hear to labour.
text.6: whom of pure origin like two strong horses aditi bore as babes in proper season.
text.7: whom mighty at your birth the mighty goddess brought forth as terrors to the mortal foeman.
text.8: as all the gods in their great joy and gladness gave you with one accord your high dominion.
text.9: as ye surround both worlds though wide and spacious your spies are ever true and never bewildered.
text.10: so through the days maintaining princely power ye prop the height as twere from loftiest heaven.
text.11: the star of all the gods established filleth the heaven and earth with food of man who liveth.
text.12: take the strong drink to quaff till ye are sated when he and his attendants fill the chamber.
text.13: the young maids brook not that none seeks to win them when quickeners of all they scatter moisture.
text.14: so with your tongue come ever when your envoy faithful and very wise attends our worship.
text.15: nourished by holy oil he this ygur glory annihilate the sacrificers trouble.
text.16: when mitravaruṇa they strive against you and break tlie friendly laws ye have established.
text.17: they neither gods nor men in estimation like apis sons have godless sacrifices.
text.18: when singers in their song uplift their voices some chant the nivid texts with steady purpose.
text.19: then may we sing you lauds that shall be fruitful dp ye not rival all the gods in greatness.
text.20: o mitravaruṇa may your large bounty come to us hither near to this our dwelling.
text.21: when the kine haste to us and when they harness the fleetfoot mettled stallion for the battle.
